value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">13</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">Of thine owne spirit which doth in me survive</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He looks back to 
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey"><choice>
              <sic>Cah cer</sic>
              <corr>Chaucer</corr>
            </choice></rs>; he descends from 
            <choice>
              <sic>Cahucer</sic>
              <corr>Chaucer</corr>
            </choice>.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It was Chaucer that gave him the <del>
            <choice>
              <sic>meausre</sic>
              <corr>measure</corr>
            </choice></del> <add hand="typewriter" place="above">
              <choice>
                <sic>stabdard</sic>
                <corr>standard</corr>
              </choice></add> by which to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">measure 
            <choice>
              <sic>hiw</sic>
              <corr>his</corr>
            </choice> own words. <add hand="ms" place="above">But</add> Where the modern writer 
            <choice>
              <sic>attackes</sic>
              <corr>attacks</corr>
            </choice> the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">actual works of some 
            <choice>
              <sic>on</sic>
              <corr>one</corr>
            </choice> of the generation that is just</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">gone, making that book the kicking off point <add hand="ms" place="above">starting point</add> in another</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">direction, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spensers</rs> revolt was against no 
            <choice>
              <sic>particualr</sic>
              <corr>particular</corr>
            </choice> writer</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">---had not years of silence intervened? <add hand="ms" place="above">who was there in English save <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey">Chaucer</rs>?</add>--- but against the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>langauge</sic>
              <corr>language</corr>
            </choice> itself, its decay, since Chaucer, its corruption.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It was partly as an antidote to his own facility; <del hand="ms">that he</del></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">needed him</del>. He found the e 
            <choice>
              <sic>ourge</sic>
              <corr>urge</corr>
            </choice> which the self critical</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">writer so often applies to his own disease in the old English</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">words that were now obsolete. A glossary was added to the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-shep" key="Shepherd's Calendar, The">Shepherds Calendar</rs> to explain them. But partly he used the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">crabbed, English of the past not as we in our day</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">seek to bring back the sharpness which much use has worn</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">smooth; but to restrain what was to come. He was, as we <add hand="ms" place="inline">are not</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">cannot be</del>, aware of the future. Everywhere, in 
            <choice>
              <sic>ballds</sic>
              <corr>ballads</corr>
            </choice>,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">songs, talk in the street, at the tavern, at the back</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">door, he heard 
            <choice>
              <sic>wit</sic>
              <corr>with</corr>
            </choice> his acute ear for sound</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">thxx something rising, moving, 
            <choice>
              <sic>buursting</sic>
              <corr>bursting</corr>
            </choice> up</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from 
            <choice>
              <sic>beanth</sic>
              <corr>beneath</corr>
            </choice> <add place="above">[illeg.]</add> the old exact words; the crabbed but precise</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">language of Chaucer. Was it not <add place="above">[illeg.]</add> to restrain that 
            <choice>
              <sic>insur ction</sic>
              <corr>insurrection</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>thzthe</sic>
              <corr>that he</corr>
            </choice> looked back to the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-cant" key="Canterbury Tales, The">Canterbury Pilgrims?</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Yet what comparison is possible between the poetry of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey">Chaucer</rs> and the poetry of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs>? The one clear, sharp,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>me erry</sic>
              <corr>merry</corr>
            </choice>; definite; 
            <choice>
              <sic>strifding</sic>
              <corr>striding</corr>
            </choice> straight on. the other sen</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>sisensuous</sic>
              <corr>sensuous</corr>
            </choice>, sinuous, dallying, winding in out of the glooms</l>
